content: Thunderbird cannot block messages, but can filter them from your view. To do that, create a filter that selects on content that is in the messages. From your post, it appears you could set the FROM to CONTAINS and enter text that is always present. To fully remove this sender, I suggest investigating to see if your email account online has a filter or spam control tool that would completely eliminate the messages.
creator: davidsk

content: Please be more specific on your problem.
creator: davidsk

content:
Just my thoughts: - I would do IMAP (although POP could work and both have similar exposure to any interruption) - check that account settings>synchronization&storage is set for offline use - set File>offline>download to ensure all headers and messages are retrieved - once you have all messages downloaded, I would create filters to separate messages into smaller groups, in Local Folders. 

   My reasoning is that Thunderbird could choke, trying to manage 22g of mail in one folder (just my opinion)

- once done, check that all messages are accounted for and then delete the IMAP account. - finally, exit thunderbird and do two backups of the profile folder with WIndows File Explorer

AND, I suggest waiting for other suggestions, as there may be other possibilities in this.
creator: davidsk

My reasoning is that Thunderbird could choke, trying to manage 22g of mail in one folder (just my opinion) - once done, check that all messages are accounted for and then delete the IMAP account. - finally, exit thunderbird and do two backups of the profile folder with WIndows File Explorer AND, I suggest waiting for other suggestions, as there may be other possibilities in this.

content: I am not sure you want to do this in IMAP, as it may synchronize with the expiring server by deleting all of the mail in your local downloads unless you archive it first! IMAP in Thunderbird is set up as a corporate mail server view port, not as a download alternative to POP, though it can download and keep local copies -- until it deletes them when the server does. I had that happen on Yahoo when it decided that IMAP could only show 10,000 messages at a time, so Thunderbird deleted the ones no longer visible, though Yahoo still had them on its web mail. Exporting those required moving them around on Yahoo to a different folder, synchronizing to it, and copying those messages to a non-sync folder in T'bird. POP is the safe way to get and keep messages, especially when you don't control the server. IMAP is the safe way for an IT department to manage what its lusers see.

creator: alalhakim

content:
I am guessing at two folders and a mapping issue: the web app puts deleted messages into "Trash", and the other apps put deleted messages into "Deleted Items", but your settings on your desktop computer and your phone are set to show you only "Deleted Items".

On your desktop, when you right click on the name of the account in the folders pane, and select "Subscribe", do you see both "Deleted Items" and "Trash" or only "Deleted Items"?

If you see "Trash", subscribe to it.

Then go to account settings - server settings, look for "When I delete a message", and see if "Trash" appears. If it does, have deleted items go to "Trash".

Then try to do the same on your phone.

My reasoning: the web app knows best. It wants deleted messages in "Trash". So you want to have deleted messages go into "Trash" on your desktop computer and your phone too, and stop using "Deleted Items".

content:
I would trust the web app's folder mappings because it is more closely connected to the server. I believe that our task is to get your apps to use the folders that the web app uses.

The only way I know of to make a folder visible in Thunderbird is the subscribe function.

In account settings - server settings, by "When I delete a message", does "Trash" appear in the list?

If you do not see "Trash" in the subscribe list of folders and you do not see it under "When I delete a message", then my theory is probably wrong, and, I'm sorry, I don't know what else to try.

content: Hello, the AllMail folder is a duplicate of all message folders and that is why Mozilla does not recommend subscribing to it, as it duplicates your disk storage and doubles time to send and receive. My suggestion, if possible, is to unsubscribe from AllMail on all devices to avoid that confusion. Deleting from AllMail on the phone causes the message to be also deleted from whatever folder the message is in.

content:
Messaggio non trovato significa di solito che c'è un disallineamento tra l'indice dei messaggi e l'archivio dei messaggi. In pratica il messaggio è ancora presente nell'indice ma è stato cancellato dall'archivio.

Il disallineamento si può correggere, ma i messaggi mancati di solito non ricompaiono. Per ripristinare quei messaggi o si scaricano nuovamente dal server (se ci sono ancora) o c'è bisogno di un backup.
creator: @next

content: Buongiorno, ringrazio. le email erano appena state scaricate dal server perché è stata cambiata la configurazione pop. Come dovremmo fare quindi per ricaricare le email?. Dobbiamo aggiungere un nuovo account pop e spostare tutte le email dello storico sul nuovo?
creator: sara.melara

content:
Per prima cosa, per evitare di peggiorare la situazione, fai un backup del profilo nello stato attuale -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/profili-thunderbird#w_effettuare-una-copia-di-sicurezza-del-profilo

Il resto dipende da qual è la situazione attuale: a) se le email sono integre e il problema riguarda solo la funziona di ricerca allora potrebbe bastare la ricostruzione dell'indice globale -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/ricostruzione-indice-globale b) se le mail invece sono vuote o illeggibili si potrebbe tentare con la riparazione delle cartelle: click destro sulla cartella che contiene la mail illeggibile -> Proprietà -> [Ripara la cartella] c) se queste due operazioni non risolvono il problema, bisogna partire dalla situazione del server: vale a dire la posta è ancora tutta presente sul server? d) se neanche questa via è percorribile l'unica cosa che rimane è ricorrere ad un backup se disponibile

Purtroppo la situazione non mi è chiara, anche la questione del cambio delle impostazioni non l'avevi segnalata all'inizio. Per cui non so dirti di preciso quale strada tentare.

creator: peterwolfs

content:
When you create a new message, the From account is the same as the account for the currently opened folder, no matter which account is the default. So, if the SBC Inbox is selected, a new message will show that account in the From box.

See also https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/identity-chooser/

Make sure your sbc account is sending on the sbc smtp, not the gmail smtp. Select an account in the left pane of Account Settings, note the Outgoing Server (SMTP) in the right pane.
creator: sfhowes

content:
The outgoing server for live, hotmail, outlook.com, msn etc. accounts is the same:

smtp.office365.com, 587, STARTTLS, OAuth2 authentication, User Name = email address.

The incoming is outlook.office365.com, 993 (IMAP) or 995 (POP), SSL/TLS, OAuth2 authentication, User Name = email address.

content: Colors and fonts are HTML attributes. Thunderbird supports such signatures, but the user is responsible for the HTML If you are not comfortable with HTML, there are some websites that help design signatures for free. If you have an email sent from your Outlook account, the HTML is probably be extracted and pasted into Thunderbird's signature field. If you can locate that and post the contents, someone here may be able to assist.

content:
You suggest things that are not coming up in my Thunderbird.

You can create a signature file by using the Thunderbird composer. As an example, open a new HTML-formatted message window in Thunderbird (File > New > Message) or click on Write located on the'Mail Toolbar'. Make sure that the formatting toolbar is displayed. There is no formatting tool bar HtmlToolbar

(If it is not displayed, you are composing a message formatted in text, not HTML. To change to HTML, select Options > Delivery Format > Rich

Above option is also not visible. I guess I just i am not cut out for Thunderbird. still trying Version 128 I think

content: Settings/Composition/HTML Style, uncheck 'Use Paragraph format...' to force single spacing after pressing Enter for new paragraph.

creator: rbsales

content:
Rick Bassett said
Thank you for the support How do I set default font for email messages for all emails? I went to setting> HTML Style and set it there, it did not set the default. Is there a way to set a default font for email messages? Thank you again, Rick

Display fonts are set in Settings/General/Language & Appearance, Advanced..., for Fonts for: Latin and Fonts for: Other Writing Systems. Keep all other font settings at defaults.
creator: sfhowes

content:
Following Sfhowes' advice, here are specifics as he indicated: And I attached examples of my own setting of Calibri 14 as my default. Here goes:

  1. in Tools>settings>general, set your default font.
  2. then click the advanced button. Notice the drop-down menu at top. It probably says 'latin' or 'other writing systems' - this is IMPORTANT:
  3. select 'latin from that menu, set your desired font and font size settings, click OK,
  4. select 'otherwritingsystems' from the drop-down menu and set the IDENTICAL settings to what you did for Latin, and then click OK. In attached screenshots you will see my latin and otherwritingsystem match. Notice I also set monospace font.
  5. if you have account set to compose HTML, then set that in tools>settings>composition to variable-width and medium font. (You would only change the HTML font setting if your intent is for recipient to receive your preferred font - not my personal recommendation.) To clarify, Thunderbird allows sender to use HTML font for themselves, yet freeing recipient to use recipient's preferred font and font size.
  6. In settings>composition, set Sending Format to 'automatic' (just my preference, not required)

NOTE: if font size is still too small, try a larger number, such as 20. the numbers in thunderbird are points, not pixels.
creator: davidsk

content: Here are normal settings for Hotmail: - incoming: outlook.office365.com, port 993, SSL/TLS, Oauth2 (assuming IMAP) - outgoing: smtp.office365.com, port 587, STARTTLS, Oauth2

I will not be able to do it without explicit direction. I never had any formal computer instruction. Where I worked we had a help desk. They didn't want us messing with settings. Before the most recent Thunderbird update I always could send to Yahoo and Hotmail just fine. Something must have changed. I wish it would just change back.
creator: carolynn1

content:
Ok, let's give a try:

  1. click the 'hamburger menu' in upper right. It appears as three short stacked bars)
  2. click 'account settings'
  3. highight the name of account of the Hotmail account on left side.
  4. now, click 'server settings' on next line. Does the first line say IMAP server or POP server? You will enter the input settings I gave you here. There is a place for server name and port number - use 995 if POP and 993 if IMAP. server name is 'outlook.office365.com, and use your full email address for user name. Connection is' SSL/TLS' and authentication is OAUTH2
  5. now, click account name again. at bottom of that pane is a link to SMTP server. click the button to edit SMTP server.
  6. on the pane, enter simple title for Description, e.g., HOTMAIL, server name is smtp.office365.com, port is 587, connection is STARTTLS, and authentication is OAUTH2, and put full email address here. Click OK and you're done for the Hotmail account.

I am not well versed on Yahoo, but this may do for your hotmail account. Steps for yahoo will be similar. I suggest you consider stopping the automatic update, which can be done at settings>general, and scroll down to that setup location and tick to notify you but not update.

content: It appears that Yahoo is delaying delivery of your messages due to potential security issues from your IP address. The error messages point to https://senders.yahooinc.com/smtp-error-codes/ with error code 421, and suggests this be pursued with your email provider, which I think is teksavvy.com.

content: There is a bug in 64-bit Version 115.18.0 under Windows: If you have defined an alternate signature to be inserted before the message for an identity of an account, the text above the signature will not have inline spellchecking. Text inserted below the signature will have inline spell checking.

content: I use Windows 7, but as an update, TB version 115.16.3 does appear to have less delays accessing my gmail accounts than the older version. It seems that rebooting my computer after the update may have improved the performance. It does hang a bit on one account or another from time to time, but not nearly as bad as the old version. content: Do you have the authentication method set to OAuth2 for the incoming and outgoing? If not, change it to OAuth2, remove the entries for the account from Saved Passwords in Settings, restart TB, enter the account password in the OAuth window to allow access.
